nodes.bodyText:
for backwards compatibility, wouldn't it be better to check for the SagaMethodMessageHandlingMember::isEndingHandler and in the orElse do the handler.hasAnnotation(EndSaga.class).
I also think that the isEndingHandler is invoked for each Saga Handler invocation. I'm wondering if it wouldn't be better to wrap an Event Handler annotated with @EndSaga with the behavior to end the Saga using SagaLifecycle.end()

Just looked at the code. It's better to deprecate the isEndlingHandler method and create a MessageHandlerWrapper that reacts on the EndSaga annotation. That way, there is no need to inspect annotations for each call, but rather only during initialization.

Was already in doubt whether I could "get away" with this simple, albeit hacky, solution.
Just added a dedicated handler enhancer definition and handling member to achieve the same.
Let me know what you think.

If you are concerned about backwards compatibility on this one, then simply ignoring the value here isn't an option. It will change the behavior to a degree that you'd much rather have a compilation error.
Since this is not likely to be a component others use directly, I suggest removing the constructor instead.

Deprecating this doesn't make sense. The method is set to return false in any case. That breaks backward compatibility already. Rather break it through a compilation error, than through a subtle change at runtime.
Since this is not a public API method, I suggest removing the it.
Exactly why I had the constructor still present in the previous review. But sure, I'll also remove this method.
